title: 105_hr4240
content: The Act is titled the "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" and addresses liability for computer date failure. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" addresses liability for computer date failure in cases where only contract-based recovery for business losses and repair costs is allowed if no personal injury is involved. The "Y2K Liability and Antitrust Reform Act" limits liability for computer date failure to contract-based recovery for business losses and repair costs, excluding personal injury. The defendant must notify all buyers of potential date failure. The defendant must notify buyers of potential date failure and provide repair or replacement for computer programs or hardware introduced after December 31, 1994. The defendant must notify buyers of potential date failure for computer programs or hardware introduced before January 1, 1995, and provide repair or replacement options. The buyer may obtain repair or replacement of the computer system or component, or obtain additional information on such system, component, program, or software. This subsection does not limit the ability of contracting parties to enter into agreements on liability and damages resulting from computer date failure. For purposes of this subsection, a "person" engaged in commerce to design, develop, or manufacture computer systems, programs, or software is defined. An action against a person for computer date failure is deemed contract-based, allowing recovery for consequential business loss and repair costs. The action for computer date failure is contract-based, allowing recovery for consequential business loss and repair costs only if certain conditions are met, such as no personal injury and reasonable efforts made to prevent the failure. The company must test its systems for Y2K compliance by simulating the transition to January 1, 2000, and take necessary precautions to prevent computer date failure by August 1, 1999. The company must provide notice of its efforts to avoid a computer date failure by August 1, 1999, including compliance efforts, test results, and likelihood of transitioning to the Year 2000 without issues. Definitions include actions to recover damages from computer date failure, breach of contract, shareholder actions, and alleged failures. The curr_chunk discusses legal actions related to computer date failure, defined as the inability of computer systems to process data accurately between 1999 and beyond. The curr_chunk defines computer program or software as a set of instructions used in a computer to achieve a specific result, and computer system as any electronic device or collection of devices. The curr_chunk defines a computer system as any electronic device or collection of devices that contains computer programs or electronic instructions and performs various functions. The curr_chunk provides a temporary antitrust exemption.
